meta.title: Fecal Secretory IgA and Mucosal Immune Function in Celiac Disease

corrections_applied: SNCD prevalence corrected: '5-15%' → '1.7-2.7% under strict criteria'
Kappler 2006 journal corrected: attributed to J Pediatr Gastroenterol Nutr
'100% sensitivity' for TG2-IgA deposits qualified with caveat re impaired mucosal IgA
TACI/TNFRSF13B discussion added as highest-priority workup
Salivary IgA added as critical discriminating test
IgG temporal trend (decline during strict GFD 2013-2019) integrated
Vaccine response testing added to recommendations
Internal contradiction resolved (impaired production vs assumed 100% deposit positivity)
Explicit evidence tiering added (Established / Emerging / Novel hypothesis)

key_diagnoses: Low IgG with selective IgG1 subclass deficiency
Low fecal secretory IgA with normal serum IgA

trend.critical_observation: IgG declined from 6.3 to 5.6 g/L during STRICT GFD (2013-2019)
trend.interpretation: Decline during optimal dietary compliance strengthens case for PRIMARY immunodeficiency

IgA_dissociation_pattern.interpretation: Normal serum IgA + severely low fecal sIgA = transport/secretion defect, not production defect

diet_timeline.2022_onwards: Grain-free (stricter than GFD alone, but still intermittent gluten lapses)

ochratoxin_A.mechanism: B-cell apoptosis, impaired CSR, MALT damage, phenylalanyl-tRNA synthetase inhibition

mycophenolic_acid.mechanism: IMPDH inhibition → blocks de novo purine synthesis → inhibits B and T cell proliferation
mycophenolic_acid.relevance: Pharmacologically active immunosuppressant at environmental exposure levels

pathophysiology_model.summary: Compartmentalized mucosal autoimmunity with convergent triple-hit immunodeficiency
pathophysiology_model.core_concept: Active celiac autoimmunity persists below serological detection threshold due to converging defects in mucosal IgA production, IgA epithelial transport, and B-cell function

component_1_primary.name: Probable TACI or CSR genetic defect
component_1_primary.evidence_tier: ESTABLISHED biology; CLINICAL PRIORITY for testing
component_1_primary.mechanism: Class switch recombination defect → selective IgG1 deficiency → impaired downstream IgA via sequential switching
evidence_for: Selective IgG1 deficiency pattern (IgG2/3/4 all normal)
IgG DECLINED from 6.3→5.6 during 6 years of STRICT GFD (2013-2019)
OTA alone would not explain selective IgG1 pattern
evidence_against: OTA exposure throughout period is confounder
Cannot confirm until genetic testing completed

component_2_secondary.name: Celiac epithelial damage causing pIgR dysfunction
component_2_secondary.evidence_tier: EMERGING — logical but pIgR in celiac unmeasured
component_2_secondary.mechanism: Villous atrophy → loss of differentiated epithelium → reduced pIgR-expressing surface area → impaired IgA transcytosis

key_evidence.shiner_1973_backflow: Shiner & Ballard (Gut, 1973; PMID 4586081) showed sIgA 'backflow' into basement membrane in untreated celiac, reversible on GFD
key_evidence.literature_gap: No study has directly quantified pIgR expression in celiac Marsh 3 biopsies

component_2_secondary.important_caveat: Pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IFN-γ) in celiac should UPREGULATE pIgR transcription via NF-κB — so dysfunction may reflect impaired function despite normal/elevated expression, not reduced expression. This is INFERRED from phenotype, not directly measured.
component_2_secondary.timeline_implication: Current sIgA measured during intermittent gluten period (2019-2025) — may reflect RECENT reversible damage
component_2_secondary.reversibility: LIKELY REVERSIBLE with complete mucosal healing (6-12 months strict GFD)

component_3_secondary.name: Dual mycotoxin immunotoxicity (OTA + MPA)
component_3_secondary.evidence_tier: ESTABLISHED for individual toxins; NOVEL for synergistic combination

mechanism.OTA: Direct B-cell toxicity, impaired CSR, MALT structural damage
mechanism.MPA: IMPDH inhibition → purine synthesis block → B/T cell proliferation inhibited
mechanism.combined: Additive/synergistic immunosuppression disproportionately targeting sequential CSR (requires two rounds of proliferation-dependent switching)

component_3_secondary.reversibility: REVERSIBLE with toxin clearance (5-6 months after exposure cessation)

double_hit_hypothesis.description: IgG1 deficiency reduces mucosal IgA production (Hit 1) while celiac epithelial damage reduces IgA transport (Hit 2), producing multiplicative reduction in fecal sIgA
double_hit_hypothesis.hit_1_production: IgG1 deficiency → fewer IgG1+ intermediates in Peyer's patches → impaired sequential CSR to IgA → fewer high-affinity IgA plasma cells
double_hit_hypothesis.hit_2_transport: Celiac villous atrophy (Marsh 3a) → reduced pIgR-expressing surface area → impaired transcytosis of whatever dimeric IgA is produced
double_hit_hypothesis.consequence: Even modestly reduced production × modestly reduced transport = severely depleted fecal sIgA

triple_hit_addition.description: Dual mycotoxins (OTA + MPA) add a third layer of B-cell suppression, compounding both production and function defects
triple_hit_addition.pharmacological_logic: MPA inhibits de novo purine synthesis required for B-cell proliferation during CSR; sequential switching (IgM→IgG1→IgA) requires two rounds of CSR and is disproportionately vulnerable

anti_TG2_gut_origin.summary: Anti-TG2 antibodies originate in intestinal lamina propria, not systemic circulation

key_data.di_niro_2012: TG2-specific plasma cells = ~10% (range 4-24%) of all duodenal IgA-secreting cells in active CD
key_data.marzari_2001: Anti-tTG isolated from ALL intestinal phage display libraries, NOT from peripheral blood (n=3; small sample limits generalizability)
key_data.iversen_2017: Clonal relatedness between gut and serum anti-TG2 IgA supports gut origin with bone marrow seeding (spillover model)
key_data.lindeman_2024: Chronic naive B cell recruitment drives extrafollicular anti-TG2 response using restricted IGHV5-51 germline

TG2_IgA_tissue_deposits.summary: TG2-targeted IgA deposits present in seronegative celiac disease at near-universal sensitivity

key_data.salmi_2006: 22/22 (100%) EMA-negative celiac patients had TG2-IgA mucosal deposits (PMID 16571636)
key_data.korponay_szabo_2004: Deposits precede villous atrophy — earliest detectable celiac marker (PMID 15082580)

TG2_IgA_tissue_deposits.sensitivity_caveat: 100% sensitivity demonstrated in patients with normal IgA production capacity. In this patient with potentially impaired mucosal anti-TG2 IgA production (IgG1 deficiency affecting sequential CSR), deposits could theoretically be diminished or absent. Sensitivity in combined SNCD + IgG subclass deficiency is UNKNOWN.
TG2_IgA_tissue_deposits.recommendation: Frozen biopsy TG2-IgA immunofluorescence remains highest-yield diagnostic test despite this caveat

sequential_class_switching.summary: Gut mucosal IgA can be generated through sequential IgM→IgG1→IgA class switch recombination

citation.title: Sequential class switching generates antigen-specific gut IgA from IgG1 B cells

key_findings.mouse: Sγ1 switch region remnants in IgA plasma cells prove prior IgG1 expression; IgG1+ B cells in Peyer's patch subepithelial dome undergo TGF-β-driven switching to IgA
key_findings.human: Bone marrow and adenoid tissue show IgA1-IgG1 as most frequent clonal pair among preferentially expanded clones
key_findings.limitation_1: Human data from bone marrow and adenoid tissue, NOT directly from human GALT/Peyer's patches
key_findings.limitation_2: Proportion of mucosal IgA from sequential vs direct switching unquantified in humans
key_findings.limitation_3: No published study has measured fecal sIgA in isolated IgG1 deficiency patients

patient_application.hypothesis: IgG1 deficiency (2.6 g/L, ref 4.1-10.1) → reduced IgG1+ intermediates available for sequential CSR in Peyer's patches → impaired high-affinity mucosal IgA generation
patient_application.confidence: NOVEL HYPOTHESIS — mechanistically sound but entirely untested
testable_predictions: IgG1-deficient patients should have lower fecal sIgA than controls (population study needed)
IgG1 restoration (if possible) should improve fecal sIgA
Peyer's patch biopsies in this patient should show reduced IgG1+ GC B cells

seronegative_celiac_prevalence.correction_note: Earlier draft stated '5-15%' which conflated old and new data inappropriately

pIgR_transport_in_celiac.established_biology: pIgR is sole mechanism for epithelial IgA transcytosis; expression regulated by TNF-α, IFN-γ via NF-κB

celiac_evidence.shiner_1973: sIgA 'backflow' into basement membrane in untreated celiac, reversible on GFD (Gut 1973; PMID 4586081)
celiac_evidence.pIgR_knockout_mice: Dramatically increased serum IgA + markedly decreased fecal IgA (Shimada 1999; PMID 10553061)

pIgR_transport_in_celiac.critical_gap: No study has directly quantified pIgR expression in celiac Marsh 3 biopsies
pIgR_transport_in_celiac.paradox: Pro-inflammatory cytokines in celiac should upregulate pIgR transcription — dysfunction may be functional (damaged epithelium) rather than transcriptional

fecal_antibody_testing_failure.summary: Fecal anti-tTG sIgA has only 10% sensitivity (Kappler et al., J Pediatr Gastroenterol Nutr, 2006; PMID 16377644)
fecal_antibody_testing_failure.reasons: Proteolytic degradation during colonic transit; tissue-binding sequesters antibodies
fecal_antibody_testing_failure.alternative: GIP testing detects antigen (resistant gliadin peptides) rather than antibody response

salivary_IgA.rationale: Distinguishes systemic vs gut-specific secretory defect

if_LOW.meaning: Systemic B-cell homing/differentiation defect across all mucosal sites
if_LOW.action: Prioritize genetic testing — confirms primary defect

if_NORMAL.action: Focus on mucosal healing — better prognosis

TACI_genetic_testing.rationale: IgG decline during strict GFD supports genetic etiology; selective IgG1 pattern consistent with pathway-specific CSR defect
TACI_genetic_testing.if_positive: Confirms primary immunodeficiency (non-reversible); family screening implications

interpretation.if_impaired: Functional immunodeficiency — may warrant IVIG evaluation

TG2_IgA_immunofluorescence.priority: HIGH — most informative for celiac confirmation
TG2_IgA_immunofluorescence.caveat_for_this_patient: Sensitivity may be reduced given potentially impaired mucosal anti-TG2 IgA production

B_cell_phenotyping.rationale: Assess B-cell maturation and class switching capacity

serial_fecal_sIgA.rationale: Biomarker for mucosal immune reconstitution after strict GFD + mycotoxin clearance
serial_fecal_sIgA.expected_improvement: If celiac-mediated component dominant, should improve over 6-12 months

IL2_release_assay.caveat: Sensitivity only 56% for HLA-DQ8+ (this patient); 90% for DQ2.5+
IL2_release_assay.implication: Negative result uninformative for this HLA-DQ8+ patient

actions.rationale: Patient intermittent 2019-2025; essential for mucosal healing
Critical discriminating test for systemic vs gut-specific defect
Binds OTA with 96% efficiency; accelerates clearance

tests.rationale: 8-17% prevalence; IgG decline during strict GFD supports genetic etiology

medium_term.milestone: After OTA clearance confirmed AND 6+ months strict GFD
tests: Consider repeat duodenal biopsy with TG2-IgA immunofluorescence on frozen tissue

if_IgG_improving.interpretation: OTA component was significant; genetic component mild or absent

if_IgG_stable_or_declining.action: Pursue extended genetic panel; consider IVIG if recurrent infections

if_sIgA_improving.interpretation: Mucosal component was celiac-mediated and reversible
if_sIgA_improving.action: Continue strict GFD; good prognosis for mucosal immunity

what_to_avoid.reason: 6-10% sensitivity; worse with impaired mucosal sIgA transport

what_to_avoid.approach: Over-reliance on serum serology for disease monitoring
what_to_avoid.reason: Patient's immunological profile makes serology structurally unreliable
Only 2/22 seroconverted after 84g gluten × 6 weeks (Syage 2023; PMID 38140342); for compartmentalized disease yield even lower

what_to_avoid.test: IgG-based celiac serology as standalone test
what_to_avoid.reason: If IgG1 deficiency impairs celiac-specific antibody production (core hypothesis), IgG-based tests are also unreliable — logical paradox

tier_1_established.claim: Anti-TG2 antibodies originate in gut mucosa
TG2-IgA deposits present in 96-100% of seronegative CD
Serum and secretory IgA independently regulated
pIgR is sole mechanism for epithelial IgA transcytosis
OTA and MPA are documented immunotoxins
TACI mutations cause selective IgG subclass and IgA deficiency

tier_2_emerging.claim: Sequential IgG1→IgA class switching occurs in gut
tier_2_emerging.limitation: Strong mouse data; human data from non-GALT sites

tier_2_emerging.claim: Celiac villous atrophy reduces functional pIgR transport capacity
tier_2_emerging.limitation: Logical but never directly measured in celiac biopsies

tier_2_emerging.claim: Mycotoxin exposure at observed levels impairs B-cell function
tier_2_emerging.limitation: Animal dose extrapolation; no human mucosal IgA studies

tier_3_novel_hypothesis.claim: IgG1 deficiency impairs high-affinity mucosal IgA via disrupted sequential switching
tier_3_novel_hypothesis.basis: Extrapolation from Siniscalco 2025 to this patient
tier_3_novel_hypothesis.key_gap: No study has measured fecal sIgA in isolated IgG1 deficiency

tier_3_novel_hypothesis.claim: Double hit (production × transport) explains severity of fecal sIgA depletion
tier_3_novel_hypothesis.status: Mechanistically coherent; no direct test possible

tier_3_novel_hypothesis.claim: Triple hit adding mycotoxins produces synergistic immunosuppression
Anti-TG2 IgA trapped between failed luminal secretion and failed systemic spillover
tier_3_novel_hypothesis.status: Explanatory model; consistent with data but unverifiable without tissue studies

arabinose.interpretation: Fungal/yeast overgrowth marker — consistent with mycotoxin-producing mold exposure

FIGLU.interpretation: Functional folate deficiency — impairs B-cell DNA synthesis and proliferation

suberic_acid.interpretation: Fatty acid beta-oxidation defect — mitochondrial dysfunction marker

vitamin_C.interpretation: Antioxidant depletion — may reflect oxidative stress from mycotoxins

systemic_IgG_IgG1.rationale: Declined during strict GFD; suggests intrinsic defect
systemic_IgG_IgG1.reversible_component: OTA/MPA effects may allow partial improvement

mucosal_sIgA.rationale: Measured during intermittent gluten period (2019-2025); may reflect recent reversible damage
mucosal_sIgA.reversibility: Likely reversible with strict GFD + mucosal healing

key_prognostic_factors: Speed and completeness of OTA/MPA elimination
Return to and maintenance of strict GFD
Presence/absence of TACI or other genetic defect
